body.p:
It was with no little anxiety that I daily
looked for the arrival of our good friend Revd. Mr Isaacs (which took place this
day a fortnight) both for himself as well as to obtain precise news from you
it was shortly after on the Evening I had an interview with him—he dined with me
on the Tuesday, and you may easily suppose that the chief topic on both meetings
which truly interested me was your affair. He delivered me your letter. I am
truly mortified at your present state and situation! Hebrew my dear brother
I will exclaim, is this the reward after 20 years labour? Hebrew
I am further wounded to find the result such of my letters such, so important, strongly
argued, and indeed such feeling ones which I addressed Mr. A. Hart on your
behalf Hebrew, my first one to him was with all the dignities & honors of Parnas,
and indeed he must have communicated it to his colleagues & friends for on
some of my observations he says this. "Neither contention or schism exist or is
likely to exist in our midst and your letter is the first intimation to myself
and the board of managers of such an event." Any passage in any part of
my correspondence you are at full liberty to show only such passages which
might be of advantage to you, but I solemnly protest that in no way whatever
touching any individual such as Mr Morais &c (as he is a friend) and any triffling
information must be kept sacred and in no way my name mingled; trusting
to your honor and integrity that such passages at all times will be kept
confidentially; Hebrew Our friend Isaacs he is a truly good & honest man
I have known something of him before his departure for America, but my
intimacy was then with his brother David, their father was a worthy person Hebrew
Hebrew. Revd S I see is this day absent, gone to Holland to the same relative
on his return to America he will give you a correct and precise account of our English
Jews, that which I have pointed out to him, and he himself has witnessed
the state of affairs; flattery, emptiness and similar saleable articles only;

no man in this world would I be so happy as to embrace and make my
friend and companion like yourself—we have not your equal here who can
work for the Jew cause as yourself, your learning, your information; but it is
not a market for genuine Gold. They dont want it, anything brass, copper &c
so that it has a gloss Hebrew as for literature dont talk of it. I know what my
old friend the great Solomon Bennett suffered who had sterling works, was it not for
the Christian friends would his work on the Temple & Engraving be out—or his
judge by my small & triffling portion of the Hebrew which I merely published to put
them to the trial, who came forward to uphold me and say let it published? it certainly
was not Dedicated to some one—but made all my brethren poor & rich one; 1000
are spent to get honors & titles. I have sent you my Dr. Sir a small sermon
through the hand of Mr. Hart which no doubt you have received. I have
had no answer still from the said gentlemen on my second letter to him 19th
Adar a reply to his remarks my conclusion to him was as follows "I addressed
myself to you candidly as a person of high station and reputation, and also
as a friend of Revd. Mr. Leeser of whom I have formed a very high opinion
and for whom I entertain great respect, admiring his talents, and
conceiving him to be a man worthy of honor and a Hebrew &c and with
your own words "that He has done more for the Jews in America than any
other Hazan." and who after 20 years in office, and now should
be out of office, I cannot but regard not only with regret—but as a
calamity." and I continued that even some little you might
have been in the fault for publishing—I fully trusted & looked from him,
and he might make use of my name to the whole of the congregation
regarding you Hebrew the love they should cherish & entertain
for a great man like yourself and who for 20 years instructed them the
word of God. I hope some of the words may have an effect. I solemnly
declare to you that I never felt for any one or God per your treatment.
Hebrew—I would at once make friends with Mr. H. for really he
Hebrew appears to have been your friend. I shall copy you his language
in his letter 25th Shebat. "When at the time he wrote the article he was aware

that two of the three meetings were for special purposes & at which the
members refused to allow any thing to be offered. (except for the purpose
called) but has also spoken of me in a manner unbecoming a friend,
let alone a friend of upwards of Twenty years standing, you will
therefore perceive that I cannot, as you say I may "freely communicate
with Mr. Leeser on the subject of your letter altho he has as you say
remark cognizance of your intention to write me." you must excuse
my long letters and in the manner they are wrote I am awaiting your
immediate answer to this and let me know precisely how affairs stand.
no doubt all the candidates are on the look out. In prayer to God may
He be Hebrew of all your opponents Hebrew that you
have been reelected in the sincere Hebrew wish of Hebrew
